summary: This is a formal letter from the French Ministry of Justice, specifically the Bureau de l'entraide pénale internationale, to the U.S. Department of Justice. It outlines the legal principles under French law that prevent the extradition of French nationals, stating that French nationality at the time of the alleged offense is an insurmountable obstacle to extradition, even if the nationality is later lost.

persons.name: Andrew PINKELMAX
persons.context: Serves as the liaison magistrate at the U.S. Embassy in Paris, acting as the intermediary for this official communication from the French Ministry of Justice to the U.S. Department of Justice.

locations: 13 place Vendôme, 75042 Paris Cedex 01, France (Address of the Bureau de l'entraide pénale internationale)
Ambassade des Etats-Unis d'Amérique à Paris (U.S. Embassy in Paris)
keyFacts: French law (Articles 696 et seq. of the Code of Criminal Procedure) governs extradition procedures.
Article 696-2 allows France to surrender non-French nationals found on its territory to foreign governments upon request.
Article 694-4 explicitly states that extradition is not granted when the requested person has French nationality at the time of the offense.
French nationality at the time of the alleged crime is an insurmountable obstacle to extradition from France.
Losing French nationality after the commission of the crime does not remove this legal barrier to extradition.
